segments.text: Richard Rodman, who had gone to the Peace Corps in Ecuador, he actually married an Ecuadorian girl later on and went in to work with the United States Agency for International Development.
And so he kind of made a life of foreign service.
And I think a lot of people really
continued to seek different kinds of opportunities in international settings after their Peace Corps work.
A lot of them went back and did work in Washington, D.C. in various parts of government programs.
What was the one memory or feeling that most stood out about your whole experience in Peace Corps?
Or two or three memories.
I'm sure there are several.
Let's see, one simple memory.
Well, of course, it's always something that indelibly is in your mind when you live through a shooting revolution.
And when we first got there, we were very idealistic.
And when the shooting war actually broke out,
And we had to get behind mattresses that were propped against the walls.
And you could actually see tracer bullets go flying across the valley.
And actually, one military post was shooting at another.
this kind of you hear planes flying overhead and bombing and you realize that you're actually part of this thing.
I guess it was pretty terrorizing.
Then later when they had the daily
I guess the curfew and I would go out in the late afternoon.
One time I stayed a little bit too late at one place and I had to go back and get to my family's house.
I had to
dodge behind a wall.

At one point I was challenged by a guard at a corner down the valley and he actually wheeled around and fired a couple shots in my direction and so I had to dive behind this adobe wall to avoid being shot.
I sort of crept along like a
an outlaw and eventually got back to the house that I was living in.
But it was just kind of this kind of tension and it's almost like being in a war zone.
How it all started, I think that was very difficult to live with.
And then as things began to settle down, I guess the real charm of the Bolivians started to come out.
And overall, they were very hospitable people.
They would invite you into their home.
And they'd really give you everything
that they have or let you share everything that they have.
I think we had really a lot of positive interaction with the people themselves.
We made a lot of friends within the Bolivian community.
We wrote letters to them many years after that.
You know, it's just one of those kind of things where you have those memories for forever.
And of course, you know, just being married in a country like that, this whole setting is almost like out of a storybook.
But I don't know if there's any one
They were good things and bad things.
We generally took advantage of every opportunity when we would have a weekend free or something to go and see as much of the country as possible.
And a lot of times we would just go out to the town square and very early in the morning,
They had these big trucks that would be going off to various places like once we went to Chulamani.
We would just go there and the people that were loading up the trucks, they would tell you where they're going.
And then so you just climb on the back of the truck and you pay them a small fee for taking you there.
And by the time you actually got there, they would stop along the way and pick up other people.
There may be a dozen people in the back of one of these trucks by the time it actually gets there.
They just have big canvas flaps over them so if it rains or whatever then they can at least keep the people dry.
But that was one of the main modes of transportation.
You just jumped on the back of one of these trucks and off you go.

During the trip itself, they would, you know, they'd have, like, some of their potatoes that are these dried potatoes, they're called chunyo, and they would have these wrapped up in their bundles on their back, and at some point they would get out their stuff, and everybody would be sharing all their food, so they'd pass around the chunyo and their various...
little tidbits of snacks that they would have.
And they'd just share it all around with everyone that was on the truck ride.
So it was really a very simple type of existence.
And you just see that the level of trusting of the people at that time was very genuine.
It may not be like that today, particularly with all of the stress of the cocaine trade and the shining path, the gorillas, these sendero luminosos that are there stirring up
additional problems in the countryside, people would probably not be as open as they were back in the mid-60s.
Maybe those times are gone forever, but it just seemed like they were almost so willing to accept foreigners and treat you like any member of their community.
share whatever they have and sort of be very open.
Maybe it was just their naive way of looking at things, but it was kind of refreshing.
It's almost like living in a very small town in the USA or something.
That's one thing that we definitely will probably remember about our Peace Corps experience.
Did you ever worry about getting sick when you ate the native foods?
Well, you always had to worry about being sick.
The water had to be boiled and also had to be filtered.
Yet, when you went someplace, like you were at a faculty
get together and somebody offered you water, you never were really sure, you know, was this boiled or was it not boiled.
And eventually, playing these kind of games, you wound up getting amoebic dysentery or you would get some kind of parasites.

My wife had amoebic dysentery while she was pregnant and the medication that you had to take in order to kill the amoebas that were eating in her liver were also very dangerous and could cause some kind of

difficulties for the for the pregnancy itself may even cause abnormal abnormalities in the fetus and so we had a lot of sort of stress and tension during pregnancy not knowing you know how it was going to work out and then as you recall from

The actual birth experience itself, when the other girl and her baby died on the same night that our first son was born, it was almost a miracle that this little five-pound infant was able to survive in that kind of a primitive setting.
But it all worked out.
Just one more question.
When you returned to the, finally returned to the States, was there a strong sense of culture shock?
What did you view differently?
When we first came back, we stopped in
Panama.
My wife had grown up in the Panama Canal Zone and she wanted me to see Panama and some of the area that she grew up in.
So we flew into Panama and we stayed in an apartment that
was a friend of hers in Panama.
She was away on vacation, so she just let us drive her car and stay in her apartment.
We had been so accustomed to living almost like from hand to mouth.
In our two years there, there were no supermarkets.
You went to the open market, you bought your little parcel of food, and you used it up in a day or two, and then you went back to the market again.
We got to Panama, into the Canal Zone, and suddenly,
You could take long showers with hot water and you go out and there's a refrigerator and you look in there and there's all this stuff.
It's just beyond belief that everything could be so easy.
You had difficulty making decisions.
Even when you went back and you went to the stores, supermarkets, and so forth, you were so overwhelmed by the variety and the packaging and so forth, you had forgotten about all this sort of thing.
And it made such an impact on you that it was difficult to deal with.
You were used to having your little string bag and having everything in a raw state with no packaging.
And then here is all this stuff that's sort of triple packaged.
And not only is there not one variety of these things, but there's 16 of them to choose from.
And you have difficulty making your purchases.
And you're just sort of awestruck.
And so it took us a while to get back into,
the idea that we do have so much and so many opportunities and we're sort of, I don't know if you would call it wasteful, but it's certainly a different kind of way to do
You know, you're selling and buying, and it's so different from the basic nature of things in Bolivia or any of the third world countries.
So I guess that was, that was definitely a culture shock for us.
just the idea of driving again in automobiles.
You don't do it for two years, you're sort of in public transit.
as you get back on the road, and everything seems to be moving much faster, you know, when you get back.
And so you're almost sort of bewildered for a while, until things begin to come back into focus.
It's just something that we notice, and we weren't quite prepared for.
And then you're sort of bombarded with things like television,
We did have radio there that we listened to quite a lot, but certainly there was no TV.
That was certainly something that we had to get used to again.
Because we were there continuously for two years.
We did have some time when we would take little trips.
We did take a trip over to Peru.
But for the most part, we were sort of in that environment continuously for the whole duration.
Have you ever done that?
We did take the children when we were in Argentina.
We took a trip back to La Paz and we went to Abraha's little hospital where David was born.
We showed the kids the apartment where we had spent our Peace Corps days and kind of retraced some of our old steps.
I think it was really a nostalgic trip for us.
I'm not sure that the kids got too much out of it, but certainly they were pretty young at the time.
They probably remember some of it, but probably not too much.
Mostly, when they go back and look at the photo albums of that period, you can continually refresh at a time when you can take it all in.

and actually think you're remembering all that stuff, but actually you're just remembering the stories that your parents tell you, and you reinforce that with the pictures, and you know you were there, and how much they actually remember.
I appreciate it.
Okay.
